title.value: S85 - Monte Carlo Based Method for Calibration of OSLDs in HDR Brachytherapy
title.justification: The title reflects the focus of the study on calibrating and commissioning optically-stimulated luminescence dosimeters (OSLDs) in high dose rate (HDR) brachytherapy, alongside developing a Monte Carlo method for dosimetry characterization, as discussed in the paper.
title.quote: Purpose: To calibrate and commission optically-stimulated luminescence dosimeters (OSLDs) for in vivo measurements in contact based treatments for superficial high dose rate (HDR) brachytherapy in place of metal-oxide-semiconductor field-effect transistors (MOSFETs).

extractions.description: This paper focuses on calibrating OSLDs for HDR brachytherapy, testing their dosimetric characteristics, and developing a Monte Carlo method for dosimetry characterization to replace MOSFETs.

type.justification: The research involves practical experiments and analysis such as testing five dosimetric characteristics, performing end-to-end tests, and comparing measured doses with expected system doses.
type.quote: Materials and Methods: Five dosimetric characteristics were tested using Landauer nanoDot^TM OSLDs.

name.justification: The research is centered on dosimetry for radiation therapy, a key area in medical physics.
name.quote: Purpose: To calibrate and commission optically-stimulated luminescence dosimeters (OSLDs) for in vivo measurements in contact based treatments for superficial high dose rate (HDR) brachytherapy.

name.justification: The paper addresses dosimetry which is specific to radiation therapy applications.
name.quote: Conclusions: OSLDs can successfully be used in place of MOSFETs for in vivo dosimetry for superficial HDR brachytherapy.

name.justification: The paper discusses the development of a Monte Carlo dose calculation software specifically for characterizing the Xoft source and investigating its dosimetry.
name.quote: Materials and Methods: A Monte Carlo dose calculation package based on the Geant4 toolkit was developed.

is_contributed.justification: The Monte Carlo dose calculation package was developed as a part of the study for dosimetry purposes.
is_contributed.quote: Materials and Methods: A Monte Carlo dose calculation package based on the Geant4 toolkit was developed.

is_executed.justification: The paper describes simulations and spectrum calculations using the Monte Carlo package.
is_executed.quote: Results: A photon splitting factor of n=100 gives rise to the same spectrum as NIST measurements and previously simulated data without photon splitting.

is_compared.justification: The results from the Monte Carlo simulations are compared with NIST measurements in the study.
is_compared.quote: The spectrum of the source was calculated with and without the bremsstrahlung splitting and compared with the NIST measurements in 178 cm from the source origin in air.

referenced_paper_title.value: Xoft electronic brachytherapy source - A Monte Carlo characterization
referenced_paper_title.justification: The work explicitly focuses on characterizing the Xoft source, suggesting reference to a broader investigation or set of literature in this context.
referenced_paper_title.quote: In order to overcome the uncertainty caused by the source to source variability in output of the Xoft electronic brachytherapy source.

name.justification: Geant4 is used as the foundational base for developing the Monte Carlo dose calculation package in the study.
name.quote: Materials and Methods: A Monte Carlo dose calculation package based on the Geant4 toolkit was developed.

referenced_paper_title.justification: Geant4 would typically be referenced as it provides the toolkit for simulation purposes in the context of the study.
referenced_paper_title.quote: A Monte Carlo dose calculation package based on the Geant4 toolkit was developed.
